paper.title: Phase-curve Evidence for an Atmosphere on TRAPPIST-1 b

core_question: Whether TRAPPIST-1 b, an Earth-sized rocky planet on a short orbit around an M dwarf, retains any atmosphere under strong stellar irradiation.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: TRAPPIST-1 b observations
datasets_or_cohorts.sample_size_or_observations: one rocky exoplanet with phase-resolved thermal spectra
datasets_or_cohorts.description: One rocky exoplanet (TRAPPIST-1 b) observed with JWST MIRI low-resolution spectroscopy over an orbital phase curve to probe day-night heat transport and atmospheric composition.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Bare-rock null scenario
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Bare-rock, no-atmosphere model with minimal heat redistribution, serving as the null hypothesis for comparison against atmosphere-bearing interpretations.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: CO2-rich atmosphere model
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Atmosphere model with significant greenhouse gas absorption, specifically designed to test for CO2 signatures around the 15 um spectral band.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: O2-rich atmosphere model
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Oxidized composition scenario with weaker CO2 signature constraints, representing an alternative atmospheric interpretation.

major_limitations: This is a single-planet study and does not establish atmospheric prevalence across all M-dwarf rocky planets.
Retrieval assumptions (circulation, opacity priors, cloud treatment) affect quantitative posteriors.
Stellar variability and instrument systematics can bias weak spectral features.
Night-side constraints are weaker than day-side constraints in the current dataset.
